ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to solve first and second order ordinary differential equations

Ability to solve ODE in general, but a deeper insight into the world of computational math. The instructor is super patient about any concept that is not previously mentioned in class and is always wiling to go over it.

I learned how to solve different types of ordinary differential equations. I solved linear, non linear, homogenous, non-homogenous, first order, second order and more equations. Overall, the class is very formulaic.

You learn how to solve different types of ordinary differential equations; it's kinda cool. I also gained a deeper appreciation for differential equations more generally, as you really gain a good sense of the wide variety of problems they are used to describe.

I learned so much in this class. First-order and second-order, linear and non-linear, constant coefficients and non-constant coefficients, we learned how to solve many diff eqs. With that said, I question the usefulness of what I learned (this is a comment on diff eqs as a class, not on the professor, Erik).
I learned various techniques to solve ordinary differential equations as well as mathematical reasoning in general.
I learned how to properly evaluate ordinary diffeqs.
How to solve various types of differential equations and how they are used, as well as the theoretical foundations for the methods.

This course brought back a lot of calculus concepts and allowed for novel insights in solving differential equations. It created a sort of roadmap for how to solve differential equations. It required a mix of problem sets and reading the textbook, and also required meeting with the professor and collaborating to fully understand the course material.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: no complaints here, it's a nice solid math class
The instructor is teaching at Yale for the first time semester, and the feedback he gives on grade scope and be confusing something.

Strengths: The class was taught in a very organized way. Everything connected and most of the class was applied. There were a few theoretical concepts, but overall I liked the class. The PSETS were great reflections of the concepts taught and the exams were very fair. 
Weaknesses: No significant weaknesses

The material is taught competently and classes are generally enjoyable. I would like to see a tad more theory, but the overall mix was pretty good. I do know that other students definitely prefer the hard applications to theory, so obviously that has to be balanced.

Strengths: 
- comprehensive overview of diff eqs.
- cohesive narrative... felt like everything ran together well
Weaknesses:
- confusing textbook... Erik was the only helpful resource for learning the material
- while it was very helpful to go over homework problems for review, practice exams would be a very useful resource

This course was strong in that the professor went through content thoroughly and had plenty of time to discuss concepts with students. However, I think the grading should have been more focused on problem sets, which represent the bulk of our work in the class, rather than a few tests that held extreme weight.
The lectures could be made more engaging but the problem sets were very straightforward.

I thought that by the end, everything came together very well. I wish we discussed applications of the work a bit more, but also given the time constraints would rather learn more methods of solving differential equations. This is a very computational course, and given that there is also an ENAS version of the course, I think this could be more proof-based in order to differentiate more from the other course. Any mention of proofs was quickly glossed over / we didn't need to know it. I think the department should recommend taking this course soon after Math 120 or other calculus because it requires integration and derivative techniques that may have been forgotten. The course material itself, though, made sense, and also the exams did not require as much calculus intricacies. I think the problem sets were all an appropriate length and reading the textbook helped a lot in understanding the material. One day in class, everyone got to write on the board and teach the class a little, which was a really great activity to feel more engaged. I think activities like this or more discussion in the course would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yeah, it's probably important to anyone interested in math or applied math
YES! Erik is an incredible professor and the material for this class is super interesting. A super fun math credit

I would recommend this class to another student. Differential equations are applicable to many real world situations and overall, solving them is very formulaic. You figure out what kind of differential equation you have and then follow certain steps.

I would take this if the material interests you. It's definitely not for everyone, but it is kinda fun to solve the different types of problems. If you enjoy solving math problems then it should be a good course for you. It isn't really proofs-y, so it is an excellent option if you are looking for a little less intense math elective. There is some theory covered and it is interesting, but it is not the focus of the course. If you are looking for something more pure, take an analysis course (or whatever else interests you).
Hmmm... only if you need it for your major
Yes, because it is a great course for anyone wanting to understand the theory of ODEs.
Yes! Especially if you need it for a major requirement
Yes! Take this class! (If its with Erik)
Yes, if you are going into a field that needs Diff Eq this course is a great introduction. The small class size facilitated student learning.

I would recommend this course to another student, but would caveat by encouraging the student to take this course soon after a calculus course, and warn that it does not have any proofs. After taking proof-based math courses, it was a bit challenging going back to computational work solely because it required relearning and refreshing earlier techniques. Also, it differs from proof-based courses because studying requires practicing as any problems as possible. However, differential equations is a useful course in any sort of field with applied mathematics and it teaches many techniques. Also, Erik was amazing and super helpful, so definitely take it with him if you have the opportunity.
